p: Subsequently, we isolated bacterial colonies resistant to 2.5 µg ml −1 of 5-FU and assumed that they had mutations of uracil phophoribosyltransferase (EC 2.4.29). Next we exposed this mutant to10µg ml −1 of 5-FU and from their sensitivity to this concentration we concluded that they retained purine nucleoside phosphorylase and thymidine phosphorylase activities. These enzymes are found in human cells too, and a deficiency of purine nucleoside phosphorylase can cause lymphospecific toxicity [14], a severe defect in T-cell immunity [15], and disorder of the immune system leading to neurologic symptoms and autoimmune disorders [16]. Thymidine phosphorylase is also present in humans and its deficiency can lead to mitochondrial neurogastrointestinal encephalomyopathy [17], [18].
